alert.note: Alert for Richland (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 18 at 11:51AM CDT until April 26 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at Wahpeton affecting Richland and Wilkin Counties. Red River of the North near Hickson affecting Cass County. Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Polk, Walsh, Grand Forks and Marshall Counties. Red River of the North at Halstad affecting Traill and Norman Counties. Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Polk and Grand Forks Counties. Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Kittson and Pembina Counties. Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Walsh, Kittson, Pembina and Marshall Counties. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY, APRIL 26... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red River of the North at Wahpeton. * WHEN...Until Wednesday, April 26. * IMPACTS...At 13.5 feet, North Main Street and bridge closed (Breckenridge). * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM CDT Tuesday the stage was 11.3 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:30 AM CDT Tuesday was 11.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 13.5 feet Friday morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
